w:r.w:t: A swimming pool is being filled with water.
Calculate the weight of the water in the swimming pool when the mass of the water is 25 000 kg.
When the swimming pool is full, the weight of the water is 1 960 000 N.
The bottom of the swimming pool has an area of 49 m
Calculate the pressure at the bottom of the swimming pool when it is full.
Choose the unit from the box.
There is a force acting on the side of the swimming pool because of the water pressure.
shows the side of the swimming pool.
Which arrow shows the direction of the force acting on the side of the swimming pool?
A child is swimming in the pool. The velocity of the child is 0.70 m/s.
The child then accelerates for 5.0 s, reaching a final velocity of 1.3 m/s.
Calculate the acceleration of the child.
shows a diving board at the side of the swimming pool.
The original length of the spring is 0.84 m.
When the child stands on the diving board, the length of the spring decreases by 0.21 m.
Calculate the percentage change in the length of the spring.
Use the Physics Equations Sheet to answer parts (f) and (g).
Write down the equation which links extension (
The force applied to the spring by the weight of the child is 336 N.
The change in length of the spring is 0.21 m.
Calculate the spring constant of the spring.
The child steps off the diving board and falls into the swimming pool.
The initial velocity of the child is 0 m/s.
Calculate the final velocity when the child has fallen a distance of 0.95 m through the air.
Give your answer to 2 significant figures.
Final velocity of child (2 significant figures) = ____________________ m/s
shows an athlete on starting blocks waiting to start a 100 metre race.
Choose the answer from the box.
The force from the athlete pushing backwards on the starting blocks
is ________________________________ the force from the starting
blocks pushing forwards on the athlete.
shows a distance-time graph for the athlete from the moment the race starts.
Three parts of the distance-time graph are labelled
of the labels to the correct description of the athlete’s motion for that part of the graph.
What distance does the athlete travel after the end of the race before stopping?
Calculate the average speed of the athlete between the start and finish of the 100 metre race.
The athlete runs faster than a typical person.
What is the average running speed of a typical person in metres per second?
Some students designed and built an electric-powered go-kart.
changes that could be made to the design of the go-kart to increase its top speed.
(b) A go-kart with a new design is entered into a race.
The velocity-time graph for the go-kart, during the first 40 seconds of the race, is shown below.
points did the go-kart have the greatest acceleration?
Give a reason for your answer.
(ii) The go-kart travels at a speed of 13 m/s between points
The total mass of the go-kart and driver is 140 kg.
Calculate the momentum of the go-kart and driver between points
(a) The diagram shows two forces acting on an object.
What is the resultant force acting on the object?
(b) BASE jumpers jump from very high buildings and mountains for sport.
The diagram shows the forces acting on a BASE jumper in flight.
The BASE jumper is wearing a wingsuit.
(i) Draw a ring around the correct answer in the box to complete each sentence.
The BASE jumper accelerates forwards when force
The BASE jumper falls with a constant speed when force
(ii) To land safely the BASE jumper opens a parachute.
What effect does opening the parachute have on the speed of the falling BASE jumper?
Give a reason for your answer.
shows the velocity-time graph for a car driven along a straight road.
the car is moving at a constant velocity.
Choose the answer from the box.
the forward driving force is _________________________ the
What word is used to describe the motion of an object that is slowing down?

shows how the stopping distance of a car depends on the speed of the car.
Describe what happens to the stopping distance of the car when the speed of the car doubles.
The ball hits the ground and bounces.
The graph below shows the velocity-time graph for the ball from when the ball is dropped until when the ball reaches the top of its first bounce.
Describe the motion of the ball between points
What direction is the ball moving between points
The ball and the Earth form a system.
A group of objects that interact.
Objects with big differences in mass.
When the ball hits the ground, energy is transferred from the ball to the Earth.
Explain how the data in the graph above shows this energy transfer.
(a) A person takes their dog for a walk.
The graph shows how the distance from their home changes with time.
Write your answer in the box.
Give the reason for your answer.
(b) During the walk, both the speed and the velocity of the person and the dog change.
A cyclist travelling along a straight level road accelerates at 1.2 m/s
The mass of the cyclist and the bicycle is 80 kg.
(a) Calculate the resultant force needed to produce this acceleration.
Show clearly how you work out your answer and give the unit.
(b) The graph shows how the velocity of the cyclist changes with time.
The velocity includes both the speed and the _____________ of the cyclist.
(ii) Why has the data for the cyclist been shown as a line graph instead of a bar chart?
(iii) The diagrams show the horizontal forces acting on the cyclist at three different speeds. The length of an arrow represents the size of the force.
, represents the forces acting when the cyclist is travelling at a constant 9 m/s?
Explain the reason for your choice.

(ii) What happens to the speed of the motorbike if force
(b) The graph shows how the velocity of a motorbike changes when it is travelling along a straight road.
(i) What was the change in velocity of the motorbike in the first 5 seconds?
(ii) Write down the equation which links acceleration, change in velocity and time taken.
(iii) Calculate the acceleration of the motorbike during the first 5 seconds.
Show clearly how you work out your answer and give the unit.
(c) A car is travelling on an icy road.
Describe and explain what might happen to the car when the brakes are applied.
factors, other than weather conditions, which would increase the overall stopping distance of a vehicle.
(a) The diagram shows an athlete at the start of a race. The race is along a straight track.
In the first 2 seconds, the athlete accelerates constantly and reaches a speed of 9 m/s.
(i) Calculate the acceleration of the athlete.
Show clearly how you work out your answer.
of the following is the unit for acceleration?

the athlete in a given direction.
(iv) Complete the graph to show how the velocity of the athlete changes during the first 2 seconds of the race.
(b) Many running shoes have a cushioning system. This reduces the impact force on the athlete as the heel of the running shoe hits the ground.
The bar chart shows the maximum impact force for three different makes of running shoe used on three different types of surface.
of the three makes of running shoe,
Explain the reason for your answer.
(ii) The data needed to draw the bar chart was obtained using a robotic athlete fitted with electronic sensors.
Why is this data likely to be more reliable than data obtained using human athletes?
Two students investigated how the acceleration of a trolley depends on the force applied to the trolley.
Before starting the investigation, each student wrote a hypothesis.
‘The acceleration of the trolley is directly proportional to the force applied to the trolley.'
‘Changing the force applied to the trolley will change the acceleration of the trolley.'
Predict what would happen to the acceleration of the trolley if the force applied to the trolley is doubled.
(b) Why is it difficult to make a valid prediction using the hypothesis of student
shows some of the equipment used by the students.
(c) Write a list of any other equipment the students will need to complete the investigation.
(d) Why should the students use a sloping runway?
To reduce the effect of friction on the trolley.
To decrease the acceleration of the trolley.
To stop the trolley rolling back up the runway.
(e) Describe a method the students could have used for their investigation.
(f) The students used the same trolley throughout the investigation.
The students' results are shown as a graph in
gives a better explanation of the results.
(a) The diagram shows the forces acting on a parachutist in free fall.
The parachutist has a mass of 75 kg.
Calculate the weight of the parachutist.
Show clearly how you work out your answer and give the unit.
In this question you will be assessed on using good English, organising information clearly and using specialist terms where appropriate.
The graph shows how the vertical velocity of a parachutist changes from the moment the parachutist jumps from the aircraft until landing on the ground.
Using the idea of forces, explain why the parachutist reaches a terminal velocity and why opening the parachute reduces the terminal velocity.
(c) A student wrote the following hypothesis.
The larger the area of a parachute, the slower a parachutist falls.’
To test this hypothesis the student made three model parachutes,
, from one large plastic bag. The student dropped each parachute from the same height and timed how long each parachute took to fall to the ground.
(i) The height that the student dropped the parachute from was a control variable.
other control variable in this experiment.
(ii) Use the student’s hypothesis to predict which parachute,
Write your answer in the box.
Give a reason for your answer.
A trolley is attached to two identical springs.
The trolley is pushed to the left and then released.
shows the horizontal forces acting on the trolley just after it is released.
(a) Write the equation which links acceleration, mass and resultant force.
(b) The trolley has a mass of 0.75 kg
Calculate the acceleration of the trolley just after it is released.
An elastic cord is fixed to the trolley.
shows the arrangement viewed from above.
When the trolley is pushed and released a wave travels along the cord.
(c) What type of wave travels along the cord?
Give the reason for your answer.
(d) Suggest one change that could be made to the apparatus shown in
to produce a wave with a lower frequency.
A bus is taking some children to school.
(a) The bus has to stop a few times. The figure below shows the distance–time graph for part of the journey.
(i) How far has the bus travelled in the first 20 seconds?
(ii) Describe the motion of the bus between 20 seconds and 30 seconds.
(iii) Describe the motion of the bus between 30 seconds and 60 seconds.
(iv) What is the speed of the bus at 45 seconds?
Show clearly on the figure above how you obtained your answer.
(b) Later in the journey, the bus is moving and has 500 000 J of kinetic energy.
The brakes are applied and the bus stops.
(i) How much work is needed to stop the bus?
(ii) The bus stopped in a distance of 25 m.
Calculate the force that was needed to stop the bus.
(iii) What happens to the kinetic energy of the bus as it is braking?
A car driver sees a dog on the road ahead and has to make an emergency stop.
The graph shows how the speed of the car changes with time after the driver first sees the dog.
(a) Which part of the graph represents the “reaction time” or “thinking time” of the driver?
(b) (i) What is the thinking time of the driver?
(ii) Calculate the distance travelled by the car in this thinking time.
(c) Calculate the acceleration of the car after the brakes are applied.
(d) Calculate the distance travelled by the car during braking.
(e) The mass of the car is 800 kg. Calculate the braking force.

examples of the physics points made in the response to explain
• on leaving the plane the only force acting is weight (downwards)
• as parachutist falls air resistance acts (upwards)

accept terminal velocity reached when forces are balanced

air resistance and weight become equal but at a lower (terminal) velocity
